trans-unit.source: Delegates define a type, which specify a particular method signature.
trans-unit.target: Delegates define a type, which specify a particular method signature.

trans-unit.source: A method (static or instance) that satisfies this signature can be assigned to a variable of that type, then called directly (with the appropriate arguments) or passed as an argument itself to another method and then called.

trans-unit.source: In order to streamline the development process, .NET includes a set of delegate types that programmers can reuse and not have to create new types. These are Func<>, Action<> and Predicate<>, and they can be used in various places throughout the .NET APIs without the need to define new delegate types. Of course, there are some differences between the three as you will see in their signatures which mostly have to do with the way they were meant to be used:
trans-unit.target: In order to streamline the development process, .NET includes a set of delegate types that programmers can reuse and not have to create new types. These are Func<>, Action<> and Predicate<>, and they can be used in various places throughout the .NET APIs without the need to define new delegate types. Of course, there are some differences between the three as you will see in their signatures which mostly have to do with the way they were meant to be used:

trans-unit.source: Action<> is used when there is a need to perform an action using the arguments of the delegate.
trans-unit.target: Action<> is used when there is a need to perform an action using the arguments of the delegate.

trans-unit.source: Func<> is used usually when you have a transformation on hand, that is, you need to transform the arguments of the delegate into a different result. Projections are a prime example of this.
trans-unit.target: Func<> is used usually when you have a transformation on hand, that is, you need to transform the arguments of the delegate into a different result. Projections are a prime example of this.

trans-unit.source: Predicate<> is used when you need to determine if the argument satisfies the condition of the delegate. It can also be written as a Func.
trans-unit.target: Predicate<> is used when you need to determine if the argument satisfies the condition of the delegate. It can also be written as a Func.

trans-unit.source: It is because of this that .NET Framework 2.0 introduced the concept of anonymous delegates.
trans-unit.target: It is because of this that .NET Framework 2.0 introduced the concept of anonymous delegates.

trans-unit.source: With their support you are able to create "inline" delegates without having to specify any additional type or method.
trans-unit.target: With their support you are able to create "inline" delegates without having to specify any additional type or method.

trans-unit.source: You simply inline the definition of the delegate where you need it.
trans-unit.target: You simply inline the definition of the delegate where you need it.

trans-unit.source: This is where lambda expressions come into play.
trans-unit.target: This is where lambda expressions come into play.

trans-unit.source: Lambda expressions, or just "lambdas" for short, were introduced first in C\# 3.0, as one of the core building blocks of Language Integrated Query (LINQ).
trans-unit.target: Lambda expressions, or just "lambdas" for short, were introduced first in C\# 3.0, as one of the core building blocks of Language Integrated Query (LINQ).

trans-unit.source: They are just a more convenient syntax for using delegates.
trans-unit.target: They are just a more convenient syntax for using delegates.

trans-unit.source: They declare a signature and a method body, but don't have an formal identity of their own, unless they are assigned to a delegate.
trans-unit.target: They declare a signature and a method body, but don't have an formal identity of their own, unless they are assigned to a delegate.

trans-unit.source: Unlike delegates, they can be directly assigned as the left-hand side of event registration or in various Linq clauses and methods.
trans-unit.target: Unlike delegates, they can be directly assigned as the left-hand side of event registration or in various Linq clauses and methods.
